You didn't mention the Faraday Cage! Both the Van De Graff generator and the car are Faraday cages. Any excess charge in a hollow conductor jumps to the surface, leaving the interior neutral. Thats what makes the VDG generator work.

When you get out of a car without touching it, the charge on your body is free to have a different charge than the car, which leads to a shock. Touching the car brings the two charges to equillibrium, preventing the shock.

As you leave the car, your body moves from inside to outside the Faraday cage. Your skin gradually becomes part of the exterior of the Faraday cage. In really dry weather, you can feel the charge move onto you as you get out.

"insulators don't conduct electricity. right?"
wrong. insulators have high resistance to the movement of electrons, while conductors have low resistance. that is the only difference between the two. enough voltage overcomes the resistance and electrons flow, with low resistance this happens very quickly. a buildup of electrons in the substance allows easy movement, as when an electron jumps into an object it then pushes out an electron where electron pressure (voltage) is lowest. this means that you don't need to overcome the entire object's resistance to get an electron to seem to flow through the object.

At 1:20 you say you can't pass charge to an insulator. Oops! Glass rods, wool socks, rugs, dry skin....these things have charges on one side different from the other BECAUSE they are insulators. If they were conductors the charges would equalize throughout the object. The styrofoam food tray picked up charge on one side of the tray which stayed there because it's an insulator.

It's worth mentioning that with all but the largest static shocks the only reason you feel them is due to the heat of the spark against your skin. In other words, the static discharge is causing you a very localised burn. This is the reason you don't feel a static shock if you touch the car door (or door handle, or metal banister) with your keys: you are isolated from the heat of the spark.
When I exit my car, I use my shoulder to touch the edge of the door before touching it with hand.

The explanation for the car is wrong. The car itself builds up an electric potential due to air friction and the tires rubbing against the road. Because of shell theorem, there is essentially no electric field inside the vehicle. However, when you get out of the car you are moving into a region where the electric field is very high - because the potential of the car is high relative to the surrounding environment. When you touch the car, your body equalizes its potential (or more accurately your equipotential pattern) to conform with the local field outside the car, and you feel that as a shock.

Nope nope nope, this is not entirely true. The reason you get zapped by your car most of the time is NOT due to friction between you and the car seat. It is due to the friction of the air against the car itself which charges the car body. Engineers already SOLVED this problem: carbon black in the tires. The carbon in the tires usually is conductive enough to discharge whatever charge builds up during driving. However, when the electrical resistance of your tires is too high, or if you have very old, non-carbonized tires, the body of your car can build up an amazing amount of charge. The instant your feet hit the ground, they are at earth potential. If you then touch the car: it will discharge through you.

Anyway: for anyone who has problems with getting zapped by their car: you can buy special rubber flaps with steel wire inside that drag over the road, called grounding straps, thus creating a nice grounding point. It will still be possible to get zapped by your car due to friction on your car seat, but that should be a very minor issue.

Also: if you get shocked by your car from friction between you and the seat, you should be able to shock yourself when you are inside the car and charge yourself up by wiggling heavily in your seat. If you're only able to shock yourself when your feet touch the ground: you need a ground strap.

+Physics Girl: I think you didn't do the story justice by not including the air friction explanation, as it is far more likely. Also: the styrofoam on top of the Van De Graaff is charged by electrostatic induction.

I'm surprised by the definition of a perfect insulator presented in this video (that it can't receive charges).

Any material can receive a charge on its surface. the difference between a conductor and an insulator is that the conductor allows the charge to move inside of it while the insulator will not allow it and the charge will stay in place until it's picked up again by some other material coming in direct contact at the exact same location.

The fact that an insulator builds a charge by rubbing it is the perfect example of this behavior.
When rubbing 2 objects together you constantly create charges on both surfaces by transferring electrons from one material to the other. If at least one of the materials is conductive the electrons will rapidly move back to their original position by moving through the conductor and cancel the charge transfer.
When both materials are insulators the charges can't move from their spot and because of the rubbing movement they're not in direct contact with their original spot anymore so they can't move back there and they're trapped until another opposite charge comes in contact long enough to allow the transfer in the other direction.

The difference between a perfect and a real insulator is the discharging spark that is explained later in the video. For an ideal insulator, whatever the voltage the charge would never move through the material and stay immobile until it's in direct contact with an opposite charge. In a real material there's some maximal voltage gradient that it can support until it lets the charge go through violently.

3:30 The launch of Apollo 12 in 1969 nearly came to disaster when, for some idiotic reason it was decided to launch the rocket in the rain, as there was no lightning in the area. However no one seemed to think about the fact that EVERY rainstorm leads to a large charge difference between the cloud and the ground. The voltage is usually not high enough to create lightning as the charge must be very high to pass through the 3000 to 5000 feet of air between the ground and the cloud.
When a bolt of lightning strikes it is so hot that it ionizes the air, making that column of air much more conductive. This then allows the cloud to discharge most of it's voltage which is why lightning tend to flicker.
In the rain storm that was over the launch pad at the time of launch the charge wasn't great enough to overcome the resistance of non-ionized air. But lightning isn't the only thing that can ionize air. A Saturn 5 rocket can to it as well. As soon as the rocket got close enough a bolt of lightning struck the rocket and followed the smoke trail to the launch pad TWICE. It was just pure luck that the only thing that happened was a bunch of circuit breakers were tripped, which the crew was quickly able to reset.
This is actually really important before you fill up at a gas station. If you are charged and cause a spark, you can ignite the fuel!

I have a GREAT point that may change how you see the car problem. I was on a moving car next to a friend who was also on a moving car, and we had to exchange some object(can't remember what it was) so we reached our hands out of the window and touched each other. The result was SHOCKING. We both experienced a significantly stronger shock than those you see when two people are electricly charged, and we were both isolated from the ground by the wheels and other factors, so the explanation I came with was that we were both electricly charged from the friction with the air, but since my car tended to move faster (and it had worse aerodynamics than the other car (looked less like a drop)) my car built more electric potential than the other. When we touched each other the electric charges on both cars rushed towards an equipotencial and we got zzzzaped . 


My point is that, theoretically, both cars would have the same electric potencial, and we only touched each other, so the flow of charges only happened within our bodies. That means that, before and after the exchange, I had the same potencial as the car, meaning I was electricly charged. And even though the car and I were on the same potencial, wouldn't that change the outcome of getting off the car and touching it? Maybe the exchange of charges wasn't complete, and the car still ended up with a different potencial. BTW, we tried that again a few weeks later alla ET, same result.

Styrofoam can develop a large static charge very easily, and it is therefore not supposed to be placed in an ESD sensitive environment where sensitive electronics can be damaged.  The fact that it is an insulator just means that it will not conduct a continuous DC current after it develops a charge.  One analogy it to think of it as a capacitor.  The center of a capacitor consists of an insulator, and will block DC current, yet the entire purpose of the capacitor is to hold a charge.

Dryer sheets DO work; we use them for laser printers with seasonal static issues and weird paper jams.  Wet the sheet damp, rub the interior and exterior surfaces with the unit unplugged, then wipe down the cartridge exterior as well (avoid the drum and the metal parts in the cartridge and printer.) The elimination of static build up solves image and paper jam issues that aren't solved any other way.  It isn't useful for 95% of printer problems but that last 5% is insoluble any other way.
